questionsData.title: The weather gets colder and …… in the mountains.
They drove ……to be in the meeting on time.
questionsData.explain_answer:
They drove fast to be in the meeting on time."

fast is an adverb that describes the speed of their driving. It indicates that they were driving quickly in order to reach the meeting on time.

  • Faster: This comparative form suggests a higher degree of speed than "fast." However, in this context, "faster" may not be the most appropriate choice because it implies a comparison with a previous speed or another vehicle's speed, which is not indicated in the sentence.

  • Slowly: This adverb suggests a low or reduced speed. However, in the given sentence, the intention was to reach the meeting on time, so driving slowly would be counterproductive.

  • Fastest: This superlative form indicates the highest degree of speed among multiple options. However, in the sentence, there is no comparison or reference to other vehicles or speeds, so using "fastest" would not be suitable.

questionsData.title: We have neighbors next door. They are always ......
questionsData.explain_answer:
We have neighbors next door. They are always  noisy .

Noisy is an adjective that describes the neighbors themselves and their tendency to make a lot of noise.

  • Noisiness is a noun, and it wouldn't grammatically fit in this sentence where you need an adjective.
  • Noise is also a noun, referring to the sound itself.
  • Noisily is an adverb, and it would describe how they make noise, but the sentence is more focused on the general characteristic of the neighbors.

questionsData.title: Samia has a ……. temper.
questionsData.explain_answer:
Samia has a good temper.

  • Good is the opposite of bad and indicates a positive quality. When referring to temper, a good temper means someone is calm, patient, and doesn't get easily angered.
  • Well doesn't directly describe temper.
  • Best is typically used for superlative qualities, and here we want to describe a characteristic, not the absolute best.
  • Worst (used twice) is clearly not what we're looking for, as it emphasizes a very negative temper.

questionsData.title: The climate is getting worse and ……
We swam in the pool, …… the cool water.
The boys ran in the streets, …… to catch the bus.
.I watched the ants ….. the seeds from the store
questionsData.explain_answer:
The correct option would be "pulling."

The sentence indicates an action that is happening in the present, so the verb form should be in the present participle form (-ing) to match the tense.

In the given sentence, "I watched the ants," the verb "watched" is in the past tense, indicating that the action of watching the ants has already taken place. Following this, we need to describe what the ants were doing at that time.

questionsData.title: He is a very ……runner.
questionsData.explain_answer:
He is a very quick runner.

"quick" is a good adjective to describe someone who can run fast.

  • Quickly and slowly are adverbs, and they modify verbs. In this sentence, we need an adjective to describe the kind of runner he is. Adjectives modify nouns or pronouns.
  • Well can be used in some contexts to describe someone's running, but it usually refers to their technique rather than their speed. For example, "He is a well-trained runner."
